comments.text:
The caller of CERT_FindCertIssuer cannot tell if it returned NULL because the cert issuer was not found or because there was an internal error.

This will cause all (or at least most) of the OCSP response processing code to return SEC_ERROR_BAD_DATABASE when the issuer cert is not available.
comments.raw_text:
The caller of CERT_FindCertIssuer cannot tell if it returned NULL because the cert issuer was not found or because there was an internal error.

This will cause all (or at least most) of the OCSP response processing code to return SEC_ERROR_BAD_DATABASE when the issuer cert is not available.
comments.creator: brian@briansmith.org
comments.author: brian@briansmith.org

comments.creator: nelson@bolyard.me
comments.author: nelson@bolyard.me
comments.text:
Brian,
CERT_ERROR_BAD_DATABASE means:
- record with desired key not found,  for read operations
- record with duplicate key found,    for write operations (that is, the write would create a record with a duplicate key if it were allowed to succeed).

It does not mean that there is any failure of the database.  
It's an unfortunate naming of this error, but that's all.
This error code has had this meaning for over 15 years now.
I don't think we should change its meaning after 15 years.

comments.author: pka@datatech.ru
comments.text: Nelson, I have complained (bug 560091 comment 1) about the lack of reference document for the error codes. Did you wrote the above from memory, or I'm missing the document ?
